title-group.article-title: Aerobic composting leachate treatment by the combination of membrane processes

contrib-group.aff: Yildiz Technical University, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Environmental Engineering Department, İstanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Mehmet Çakmakcı, Yildiz Technical University, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Environmental Engineering Department, 34220 Davutpaşa-Esenler, Istanbul, Turkey. Email: cakmakci@yildiz.edu.tr

abstract.p:
The main product of the conversion process of organic wastes to a useful organic fertilizer, known as compost, has gained an increasing interest in management of organic wastes recently. One of the main problems arising in the composting facilities is the high organic loaded leachate. In this study, a treatability experiment for composting leachate from a full-scale composting facility was carried out with the combination of membrane processes. The parameters such as chemical oxygen demand, total organic carbon, Cl− and
NH
4 +
were analysed to evaluate the membrane treatment performances of single and combined membrane systems consisting centrifuge, cartridge filter, ultrafiltration and nanofiltration membranes. The removal efficiencies of all pollutants were observed between 4.4 and 98%. The highest removal efficiencies were observed with the nanofiltration membrane (NF90) having a lower molecular weight cut-off than the others used in this study. It was observed that the effluent of NF90 membrane did not exceed the allowed maximum COD value.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Composting, one of the organic waste recycling methods, converts organic waste materials into an organic fertilizer or compost used in gardens, parks and other green areas. Additionally, it has a wide application as a soil conditioner for barren areas. Composting leachate is comprised of the run-off of liquids through active compost in the course of the composting process. Leachate is mostly affected by factors such as the contents of feedstock, maturity period, composting technology and climate conditions (Tyrrel et al., 2008). Composting leachate has a high organic load due to fresh organic wastes. Moreover, composting leachate includes nutrients and dissolved salts as well as organic matter. The discharging of composting leachate without any treatment can cause serious environmental problems (Mokhtarani et al., 2011; Trujillo et al., 2006). There are limited studies on the treatment of composting leachate (Gagnaire et al., 2012; Mokhtarani et al., 2011; Rajabi and Vafajoo, 2012; Savage and Tyrrel, 2005; Tyrrel et al., 2008). Composting leachate can be treated by biological and/or physico-chemical treatment methods. Mokhtarani et al. (2011) and Rajabi and Vafajoo (2012) used a hybrid anaerobic system as a biological treatment for composting leachate and they observed chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal efficiency of 91%. In another study, Savage and Tyrrel (2005) and Tyrrel et al. (2008) used biofilters for ammonia nitrogen removal from composting leachate and they recorded removal efficiency of greater than 95%. Chemical treatment processes for composting leachate treatment were used by Trujillo et al. (2006), Maleki et al. (2009) and Gagnaire et al. (2012). Trujillo et al. (2006) removed 75–77% of COD and 90–98% of BOD with the Fenton process. Maleki et al. (2009) used ferric chloride and aluminum sulfate and achieved a COD removal rate of 18% with aluminum sulfate and 28% with ferric chloride. Gagnaire et al. (2012) used physico-chemical treatment processes for composting leachate. They obtained an ammonium removal rate of 90% with the addition of lime and were able to reach 93% ammonium removal rate with the combination of ultrafiltration and a reverse osmosis membrane process. The COD removal efficiency observation by the combination of lime, drum filter, ultrafitration and reverse osmosis membrane was also 95%.

This study presents the results of physical treatment processes for the treatment of composting leachate from a full-scale composting facility. For this purpose, a centrifuge, cartridge filters, ultrafiltration, and nanofiltration (NF) membranes were used for pre-treatment and advanced treatment of composting leachate.

sec.title: Composting leachate
sec.p:
The composting facility has been in operation for 10 years and is located in Kemerburgaz, Istanbul. The facility has a daily treatment capacity of 1000 tonnes. Mixed municipal solid waste is aerobically composted by a tunnel composting system. Food waste has the largest percentage in the incoming mixed municipal solid waste. Composting is completed in 8 weeks. Leachate generation in the facility is about 45 m3 day−1 (Altinbas, 2007). Composting leachate samples taken from the facility were stored at +4 °C until usage. The composition of the leachate varied greatly depending on the feed stock properties. It was a dark black-coloured alkaline mixture and had a very high concentration of organic matter, salinity, nitrogen and suspended solids (SS). The average COD/total organic carbon (TOC) ratio was around 2.3, which is approximately the molecular ratio of oxygen to carbon, stoichiometrically. Other major components present in the leachate were
NH
4 +
and Cl− with high concentrations of 754 and 3059 mg L−1, respectively. The composting leachate contained COD (23900 ± 1000.0 mg L−1), TOC (10340 ± 500.0 mg L−1), total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) (1495 ± 50.0 mg L−1), SS (1820 ± 75.0 mg L−1), Cl− (3059 ± 150.0 mg L−1) and
NH
4 +
(754 ± 50.0 mg L−1). pH and conductivity were measured as 7.6 ± 0.5 and 23 ± 2.0 mS cm−1, respectively. All parameters were analysed according to the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater (APHA/AWWA/WEF 2005). COD was analysed using the 5220 C (closed reflux) method in Standard Methods. A Hach-Lange IL-550 Model TOC analser was used for TOC analysis according to method number of 5310 B in Standard Methods. Cl− and
NH
4 +
were analysed by an ICS-3000 Ion Chromatography System-Dionex.

sec.title: Membranes
sec.p: A 5 µm cartridge filter and UC030 membranes were used as pre-treatment membranes. NP030, NP010, NF270 and NF90 type membranes were used as advanced treatment membranes. The UC030, NP010 and NP030 membranes were manufactured by Microdyn Nadir and the NF270 and NF90 membranes were manufactured by Dow-Filmtec. The specific properties of the membranes used in this study are summarized in Table 1.

fn.p: RC, resistant cellulose; PES, polyethersulfone; PA-TFC, polyamide thin-film composite; *Kovacs and Samhaber (2008).

sec.title: Experimental set-up and procedures
sec.p: The experiments were carried out in a laboratory-scale flat sheet membrane set-up having a specific membrane area of 155 cm2. The retained stream was re-circulated to the feed tank, while the permeate stream was collected in a beaker on the digital balance to calculate membrane flux. The feed tank was kept at 25 °C with a heat exchanger. A Beckman Coulter Allegra X-12 centrifuge was used to remove SS. The centrifuge was operated at 3750 rpm for 30 min. Membranes were operated under different transmembrane pressures (TMP). Each pressure test was carried out with a new membrane in order to minimize interference from membrane clogging.

Pre-treatment was applied as an essential step to prevent clogging of the membrane units in the advanced treatment processes because composting leachate has a high concentration of SS. For this purpose, two pre-treatment options were used. At the first step of the experimental studies, raw composting leachate was passed directly through a 5 µm cartridge filter and UC030 membrane. In the second part of the experimental studies, composting leachate was centrifuged in order to remove SS before the cartridge filter. After those steps, the UC030 membrane was finally used as a part of the pre-treatment units. In both steps, the UC030 membrane was operated under a TMP of 3 bar for 24 h.

The NP030, NP010, NF270 and NF90 membranes were used in this study as advanced treatment units. The operating pressures of the membranes were determined by considering observed flux values. Starting from this point, initial operating pressures were determined. Thereafter, nanofiltration membranes of NP010 and NF270 were operated under TMPs of 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10.0 bar. Similarly, operating TMPs of NP030 and NF90 membranes were applied as 10.0, 15.0, 20.0 and 25.0 bar.

sec.title: Pre-treatment
sec.p: The flux variations of the UC030 membrane with and without using the centrifuge are shown in Figure 1. Centrifuging had a positive effect on the flux of the UC030 membrane due to removal of SS. At the end of the 24-h studies the flux values with and without centrifuging were close to each other, with values of 12.7 and 14.0 L m−2 h−1, respectively.

caption.p: Flux variation of UC030 membrane (5 µm cartridge filter + UC030 with (dotted line) and without (solid line) centrifuge unit).

sec.p: A rapid decrease in the flux in the un-centrifuged study was seen at the initial stage (Figure 1). It was assumed that a cake layer rapidly formed on the membrane surface due to the coarse particles in the composting leachate. Thereafter the membrane flux slowly declined. In contrast to the first pre-treatment study, from the beginning the flux in the centrifuged study slowly decreased. This behaviour was considered to be due to the presence of some higher and some finer particulates affecting the formation of the cake layer on the membrane surface which were removed by centrifuge treatment.

After centrifuging, the COD and TOC concentrations were found to be 19850 and 9649 mg L−1, respectively. The COD and TOC concentrations in permeates of the first and second pre-treatment steps were measured as 15 750 and 6765 mg L−1, and 14 400 and 6330 mg L−1, respectively.

It was observed that the removal efficiency of the combination of the centrifuge + 5 µm cartridge filter + UC030 was slightly higher than the experiment without centrifugation. Similarly, Uygur and Kargı (2004) found nearly similar removal rates for COD with centrifuged landfill leachate.

Ion concentrations of Cl− and
NH
4 +
were not significantly removed with pre-treatment membranes in this study.

sec.title: Advanced treatment
sec.p: The effects on flux of different TMPs for NF270 membrane are shown in Figure 2(a) and (b). As would be expected, the NF270 membrane flux was increased with elevated TMPs for both centrifuged and non-centrifuged pre-treatments. However, Figure 2(c) and (d) illustrate the flux variations of all NF membranes used with the highest TMPs applied. The maximum flux value was 155.2 L m−2 h−1 with NP010, whereas the minimum flux was 28.0 L m−2 h−1 with the NF90 membrane. It was assumed that this was because the NF90 membrane had a lower molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) (150 Da) than NP010 (1040–1400 Da) membrane. On the contrary, NP030 (500–700 Da) had a higher MWCO than NF270 (200–300 Da), whereas the flux of the NP030 membrane was lower than the NF270 membrane. The reason for the difference was considered to be that the NP030 and NF270 membranes were manufactured from different materials (Table 1). Therefore, it was considered that MWCO and the produced materials had an important effect on the flux of the NF membranes used for composting leachate treatment. The fluxes of the centrifuged composting leachate were slightly higher than the non-centrifuged fluxes except for the NP010 membrane (Figure 2(c) and (d)), due to the removal of some colloidal materials by the centrifuge process. By considering the applied TMP values, according to flux values the NF membranes could be ordered as NP010 > NF270 > NP030 > NF90.

caption.p: Variation of flux values variations of: (a) NF270; (b) centrifuged-NF270; (c) NF membranes; and (d) centrifuged-NF membranes.

sec.p: The high concentration of organic matter in the composting leachate is one of the most important pollutant sources for receiving bodies. The COD and TOC removal performances of the NF membranes are shown in Figure 3 and Table 2. The highest COD and TOC removal efficiency was recorded with the NF90 membrane. The effluent COD concentrations of the NF90 membranes ranged from 225 to 425 mg L−1. The COD removal efficiencies of this membrane were observed to be 97.3–98.7%. As with COD, the TOC removal rates were also observed to be over 97% with the NF90 membrane. The TOC concentrations in the permeate ranged from 130 to 159 mg L−1 with removal efficiencies of 97.6 to 98.1% for non-centrifuged pre-treatment. With centrifuged pre-treatment, the effluent COD concentrations for the NF90 membrane were observed to range from 945 to 3510 mg L−1 and the corresponding removal efficiencies were between 78.6 and 93.6%. Effluent TOC concentrations were measured and found to be between 404 and 1356 mg L−1 and the corresponding removal rates were between 76.9 and 93.9%.

caption.p: Removal efficiency of: (a) COD; (b) centrifuged-COD; (c) TOC; and (d) centrifuged-TOC.
Performances of the advanced treatment membranes.

tr.th: Centrifuge +5 µm cf + UC030 + NF membranes

sec.p: The removal rates of COD and TOC varied between 50.5 and 88.1% for NF270. Furthermore, the observed removal rates were lower than 53.5% for NP030 (500–700 Da), and lower than 36.9% for NP010 (1040–1400 Da) membranes. The main reason for these results was considered to originate from the MWCO. Smaller MWCO values may increase the removal efficiency. Contrary to the order of MWCO, the NF membranes were ordered as NF90 > NF270 > NP030 > NP010 in terms of the removal efficiency of COD and TOC.

In the present study, a COD removal efficiency of up to 98.7% was achieved with the physical membrane process (5 µm cartridge filter + UC030 (30 kDa) + NF90 (150 Da)) for composting leachate treatment. Gagnaire et al. (2012) used a similar combination of a chemical and physical membrane system. They recorded a COD removal efficiency of 94% with the combined system of lime + drum filter + UF (150 kDa) + reverse osmosis (RO) membrane. The applied TMPs used by Gagnaire et al. (2012) were higher for the UF (5 bar) and RO (30 bar) membranes than those applied in this study for UF (3 bar) and NF90 (25 bar).

The discharge standard of solid waste evaluation and disposal facilities is stated in Table 20.6 of the Turkish Water Pollution Control Regulation (TWPCR, 2004). Limit values for COD, TKN and pH are defined in this table as 700 mg L−1, 20 mg L−1 and 6–9. The combination of a 5 µm cartridge filter + UC030 + NF90 membrane yielded results that did not exceed the allowed maximum COD value stated in the Turkish standard.

In the present study, monovalent ion (Cl− and
NH
4 +
) removal performance was also tested. The removal performance of NF membranes for Cl− and
NH
4 +
are shown in Figure 4 and Table 2. The highest removal efficiency for both ions was obtained with the NF90 membrane, whereas the lowest was achieved with theNP010 membrane. The removal efficiency of Cl− by the NF90 membrane varied between 237 mg L−1 (91.9%) and 450 mg L−1 (84.7%) with no centrifuge pre-treatment, and between 466 mg L−1 (84.2%) and 1030 mg L−1 (65.1%) with centrifuge pre-treatments. The other membranes used in this study resulted in a Cl− removal performance that was lower than 40% in general.

caption.p:
Removal efficiency of: (a) Cl−; (b) centrifuged-Cl−; (c)
NH
4 +
; and (d) centrifuged-
NH
4 +
.

sec.p:
NH
4 +
concentrations of the NF90 membrane with no centrifuge pre-treatment varied between 106 mg L−1 (85.2%) and 154 mg L−1 (78.7%). With the addition of the centrifuge pre-treatment the concentrations observed were between 145 mg L−1 (80.1%) and 243 mg L−1 (66.6%). The
NH
4 +
removal performance of other membranes was generally below 50%. In another study, ammonium removal efficiency with lime addition was recorded as 90% by Gagnaire et al. (2012), and 95% with a bio-filter by Savage and Tyrrel (2005) and Tyrrel et al. (2008). In spite of the NF90 membrane having high
NH
4 +
removal performance, the present results were lower than values found in other literature studies because of the testing membrane combination used in the present study and without using any chemical and/or biological process. In the present study, the removal performances of Cl− and
NH
4 +
ions for NF membranes were ordered as NF90 > NF270 > NP030 > NP010. Consequently, the NF90 membrane had the best performance both for organic content and ion removal from composting leachate, whereas the lowest removal rates were observed for the NP010 membranes. It was obvious that the physical treatment processes did not meet the standards for
NH
4 +
. Chemical or biological pre-treatment is required to meet the standards of
NH
4 +
by membrane process.

The effects of TMP on the membrane performance can be seen in Figures 3 and 4. Elevated TMP generally increased the removal performance of both organic matter and monovalent ions with NF90 and NF270. NP010 and NP030 were usually negatively affected by the elevated TMP. These membranes have a higher MWCO and the elevated TMP on the cake layer might need to be increased to pass the pollutant into permeate. The NF90 and NF270 membranes have lower MWCO and the elevated TMP might compress the cake layer on the membrane surface and this compressed cake layer might have acted as a new filtration area.

The removal efficiencies of both organic matter and monovalent ions were affected by the centrifuge pre-treatment (Figures 3 and 4). NF90 performance was mostly negatively affected by centrifuge pre-treatment. After centrifuging, the cake layer occurring on the UC030 membrane was retarded and so some of the soluble organics and ions which might be retained on the cake layer of the UC030 with no centrifuge pre-treatment might not be removed by UC030. Therefore, the performance of the NF membranes was negatively affected by the centrifuge treatment. In addition to a decline in the membrane performance, the centrifuge treatment consumed high amounts of energy. As a result, it was considered that centrifuge treatment was not suitable as a pre-treatment option for composting leachate treatment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Composting leachate includes a high concentration of pollutants such as organic matter and nutrients. These pollutants may lead to serious environmental problems. In the present study, the treatability of composting leachate by membrane processes was investigated. Centrifuge, cartridge filter and UF membrane, and four types of NF membranes were used in the treatability studies. The main results of these experiment sets are summarized in the following list.

list-item.p:
Using a centrifuge in the treatment process has a positive effect on flux, but there is a negative effect on the removal performance of organic matter and ions (Cl− and
NH
4 +
) for NF membranes

The lowest removal efficiency of organic matter and ions with the highest flux was observed for NP010 membranes. On the other side, the lowest flux and highest removal performance was observed for NF90 membranes.
The MWCO and manufacturing materials of NF membrane significantly affects both flux and removal efficiency.

sec.p: This study shows that new pre-treatment options should be used to increase both the flux and the removal efficiency of the membrane processes. Therefore, further research on the use of the membrane processes to treat composting leachate should be focused on the combination of biological treatment and membrane processes. Organic matter with lower molecular weight, which may easily pass through the membrane, can be utilized by micro-organisms in the biological process. By this process flow, the organic load of the membrane may be decreased and higher removal efficiencies of membranes can be expected.
This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
